title: 105_hr2535
content: The Emergency Student Loan Consolidation Act of 1997, also known as the Act, refers to the Higher Education Act of 1965. It allows for loan consolidation provisions. The Emergency Student Loan Consolidation Act of 1997, part of the Higher Education Act of 1965, allows for the consolidation of eligible student loans made under part D of the title. Loans must be consolidated within a specific timeframe outlined in the Act. The Emergency Student Loan Consolidation Act of 1997 allows for the consolidation of eligible student loans within a specific timeframe. Amendments include changes to the application deadline for consolidation loans received by eligible lenders. The Emergency Student Loan Consolidation Act of 1997 allows for loan consolidation within a specified period. An amendment ensures nondiscrimination by eligible lenders when providing consolidation loans. The Emergency Student Loan Consolidation Act of 1997 allows for loan consolidation without discrimination based on various factors such as the number or type of eligible student loans, the type of institution attended, interest rates, or repayment schedules. Amendments to Section 428C(c)(1) include expanding the types of loans eligible for consolidation. Consolidation loans under the Emergency Student Loan Consolidation Act of 1997, received by eligible lenders between enactment and October 1, 1998, will bear interest at a specified rate. Amendments made by this section apply to pending applicants. Loans authorized by this section are available even if a student withdraws their application for a consolidation loan under the Higher Education Act of 1965 before receiving it. SEC. 3. ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSE REDUCTIONS. Amends Section 458(a)(1) to reduce administrative expenses from $532,000,000 to $507,000,000. SEC. 4. TREATMENT OF TAX BENEFITS. Family Contribution for Dependent Students is amended to include parents' available income and any tax credit taken under section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Student contribution from available income is also amended. The text discusses amendments to the Family Contribution for Independent Students, including the inclusion of any tax credit taken under section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments are made to the Family Contribution for Independent Students, including the inclusion of any tax credit taken under section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This involves adjustments to various sections such as 477(b)(1), 480(a)(2), and 480(j) of the U.S.C. Amendments include excluding tax credits under section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 from being considered as estimated financial assistance for section 471(3) purposes. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 21, 1997. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
